post.description: Retrieves an existing job definition.

AllocatedCapacity.description:
This field is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) allocated to runs of this job. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

Command.description: The JobCommand that executes this job.

Name.description: The name of the job command: this must be glueetl, for an Apache Spark ETL job, or pythonshell, for a Python shell job.

ScriptLocation.description: Specifies the S3 path to a script that executes a job (required).

Connections.description: The connections used for this job.
A list of connections used by the job.

CreatedOn.description: The time and date that this job definition was created.

DefaultArguments.description:
The default arguments for this job, specified as name-value pairs.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

Description.description: Description of the job being defined.

ExecutionProperty.description: An ExecutionProperty specifying the maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for this job.

MaxConcurrentRuns.description: The maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for the job. The default is 1. An error is returned when this threshold is reached. The maximum value you can specify is controlled by a service limit.

LastModifiedOn.description: The last point in time when this job definition was modified.

LogUri.description: This field is reserved for future use.

MaxCapacity.description:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

MaxRetries.description: The maximum number of times to retry this job after a JobRun fails.

Name.description: The name you assign to this job definition.

NotificationProperty.description: Specifies configuration properties of a job notification.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

Role.description: The name or ARN of the IAM role associated with this job.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job.

Timeout.description: The job timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

JobName.description: The name of the job definition to retrieve.

post.description: Retrieves the metadata for a given job run.

AllocatedCapacity.description:
This field is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) allocated to this JobRun. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

Arguments.description:
The job arguments associated with this run. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

Attempt.description: The number of the attempt to run this job.

CompletedOn.description: The date and time this job run completed.

ErrorMessage.description: An error message associated with this job run.

ExecutionTime.description: The amount of time (in seconds) that the job run consumed resources.

Id.description: The ID of this job run.

JobName.description: The name of the job definition being used in this run.

JobRunState.description: The current state of the job run.

LastModifiedOn.description: The last time this job run was modified.

LogGroupName.description: The name of the log group for secure logging, that can be server-side encrypted in CloudWatch using KMS. This name can be /aws-glue/jobs/, in which case the default encryption is NONE. If you add a role name and SecurityConfiguration name (in other words, /aws-glue/jobs-yourRoleName-yourSecurityConfigurationName/), then that security configuration will be used to encrypt the log group.

MaxCapacity.description:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

PredecessorRuns.description: A list of predecessors to this job run.

items.description: A job run that was used in the predicate of a conditional trigger that triggered this job run.

JobName.description: The name of the job definition used by the predecessor job run.

RunId.description: The job-run ID of the predecessor job run.

PreviousRunId.description: The ID of the previous run of this job. For example, the JobRunId specified in the StartJobRun action.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job run.

StartedOn.description: The date and time at which this job run was started.

Timeout.description: The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

TriggerName.description: The name of the trigger that started this job run.

JobName.description: Name of the job definition being run.

PredecessorsIncluded.description: True if a list of predecessor runs should be returned.

RunId.description: The ID of the job run.

DatabaseName.description: The name of the catalog database where the partitions reside.

Expression.description:
An expression filtering the partitions to be returned.

The expression uses SQL syntax similar to the SQL WHERE filter clause. The SQL statement parser JSQLParser parses the expression.

Operators: The following are the operators that you can use in the Expression API call:

=

Checks if the values of the two operands are equal or not; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: Assume 'variable a' holds 10 and 'variable b' holds 20.

(a = b) is not true.

< >

Checks if the values of two operands are equal or not; if the values are not equal, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a < > b) is true.

>

Checks if the value of the left operand is greater than the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a > b) is not true.

<

Checks if the value of the left operand is less than the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a < b) is true.

>=

Checks if the value of the left operand is greater than or equal to the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a >= b) is not true.

<=

Checks if the value of the left operand is less than or equal to the value of the right operand; if yes, then the condition becomes true.

Example: (a <= b) is true.

AND, OR, IN, BETWEEN, LIKE, NOT, IS NULL

Logical operators.

Supported Partition Key Types: The following are the the supported partition keys.

  • string

  • date

  • timestamp

  • int

  • bigint

  • long

  • tinyint

  • smallint

  • decimal

If an invalid type is encountered, an exception is thrown.

The following list shows the valid operators on each type. When you define a crawler, the partitionKey type is created as a STRING, to be compatible with the catalog partitions.

post.description: Retrieves the definition of a trigger.

Actions.description: The actions initiated by this trigger.

items.description: Defines an action to be initiated by a trigger.

Arguments.description:
The job arguments used when this trigger fires. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

JobName.description: The name of a job to be executed.

NotificationProperty.description: Specifies configuration properties of a job run notification.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this action.

Timeout.description: The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

Id.description: Reserved for future use.

Predicate.description: The predicate of this trigger, which defines when it will fire.

Conditions.description: A list of the conditions that determine when the trigger will fire.

items.description: Defines a condition under which a trigger fires.

JobName.description: The name of the Job to whose JobRuns this condition applies and on which this trigger waits.

State.description: The condition state. Currently, the values supported are SUCCEEDED, STOPPED, TIMEOUT and FAILED.

Logical.description: Optional field if only one condition is listed. If multiple conditions are listed, then this field is required.

Schedule.description: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

State.description: The current state of the trigger.

Type.description: The type of trigger that this is.

Name.description: The name of the trigger to retrieve.

Timeout.description: The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

Id.description: Reserved for future use.

Predicate.description: The predicate of this trigger, which defines when it will fire.

Conditions.description: A list of the conditions that determine when the trigger will fire.

items.description: Defines a condition under which a trigger fires.

JobName.description: The name of the Job to whose JobRuns this condition applies and on which this trigger waits.

State.description: The condition state. Currently, the values supported are SUCCEEDED, STOPPED, TIMEOUT and FAILED.

Logical.description: Optional field if only one condition is listed. If multiple conditions are listed, then this field is required.

Schedule.description: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

State.description: The current state of the trigger.

Type.description: The type of trigger that this is.

DependentJobName.description: The name of the job for which to retrieve triggers. The trigger that can start this job will be returned, and if there is no such trigger, all triggers will be returned.

MaxResults.description: The maximum size of the response.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if this is a continuation call.

post.description: Retrieves a specified function definition from the Data Catalog.

ClassName.description: The Java class that contains the function code.

CreateTime.description: The time at which the function was created.

ResourceUris.description: The resource URIs for the function.

items.description: URIs for function resources.

Uri.description: The URI for accessing the resource.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog where the function to be retrieved is located. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.description: The name of the catalog database where the function is located.

post.description: Retrieves a multiple function definitions from the Data Catalog.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if the list of functions returned does not include the last requested function.

UserDefinedFunctions.description: A list of requested function definitions.

items.description: Represents the equivalent of a Hive user-defined function (UDF) definition.

ClassName.description: The Java class that contains the function code.

CreateTime.description: The time at which the function was created.

items.description: URIs for function resources.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of functions to return in one response.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if this is a continuation call.

Pattern.description: An optional function-name pattern string that filters the function definitions returned.

post.description: Imports an existing Athena Data Catalog to AWS Glue

CatalogId.description: The ID of the catalog to import. Currently, this should be the AWS account ID.

post.description:
Retrieves the names of all crawler resources in this AWS account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.

This operation takes the optional Tags field which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag will be retrieved.

CrawlerNames.description: The names of all crawlers in the account, or the crawlers with the specified tags.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if the returned list does not contain the last metric available.

MaxResults.description: The maximum size of a list to return.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if this is a continuation request.

Tags.description: Specifies to return only these tagged resources.

This operation takes the optional Tags field which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag will be retrieved.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if the returned list does not contain the last metric available.

post.description: Sets the security configuration for a specified catalog. After the configuration has been set, the specified encryption is applied to every catalog write thereafter.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog for which to set the security configuration. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

ConnectionPasswordEncryption.description: When connection password protection is enabled, the Data Catalog uses a customer-provided key to encrypt the password as part of CreateConnection or UpdateConnection and store it in the ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD field in the connection properties. You can enable catalog encryption or only password encryption.

AwsKmsKeyId.description:
An AWS KMS key that is used to encrypt the connection password.

If connection password protection is enabled, the caller of CreateConnection and UpdateConnection needs at least kms:Encrypt permission on the specified AWS KMS key, to encrypt passwords before storing them in the Data Catalog.

You can set the decrypt permission to enable or restrict access on the password key according to your security requirements.

ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted.description: When the ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted flag is set to "true", passwords remain encrypted in the responses of GetConnection and GetConnections. This encryption takes effect independently from catalog encryption.

EncryptionAtRest.description: Specifies the encryption-at-rest configuration for the Data Catalog.

CatalogEncryptionMode.description: The encryption-at-rest mode for encrypting Data Catalog data.

SseAwsKmsKeyId.description: The ID of the AWS KMS key to use for encryption at rest.

post.description: Sets the Data Catalog resource policy for access control.

PolicyHash.description: A hash of the policy that has just been set. This must be included in a subsequent call that overwrites or updates this policy.

PolicyExistsCondition.description: A value of MUST_EXIST is used to update a policy. A value of NOT_EXIST is used to create a new policy. If a value of NONE or a null value is used, the call will not depend on the existence of a policy.

PolicyHashCondition.description: The hash value returned when the previous policy was set using PutResourcePolicy. Its purpose is to prevent concurrent modifications of a policy. Do not use this parameter if no previous policy has been set.

PolicyInJson.description: Contains the policy document to set, in JSON format.

post.description: Resets a bookmark entry.

JobName.description: Name of the job in question.
The name of the job in question.

post.description: Starts a crawl using the specified crawler, regardless of what is scheduled. If the crawler is already running, returns a CrawlerRunningException.

Name.description: Name of the crawler to start.

post.description: Changes the schedule state of the specified crawler to SCHEDULED, unless the crawler is already running or the schedule state is already SCHEDULED.

CrawlerName.description: Name of the crawler to schedule.

post.description: Starts a job run using a job definition.

JobRunId.description: The ID assigned to this job run.

AllocatedCapacity.description:
This field is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) to allocate to this JobRun. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

Arguments.description:
The job arguments specifically for this run. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

JobName.description: The name of the job definition to use.

JobRunId.description: The ID of a previous JobRun to retry.

MaxCapacity.description:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

NotificationProperty.description: Specifies configuration properties of a job run notification.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job run.

Timeout.description: The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

post.description: Starts an existing trigger. See Triggering Jobs for information about how different types of trigger are started.

Name.description: The name of the trigger that was started.
The name of the trigger to start.

post.description: If the specified crawler is running, stops the crawl.

Name.description: Name of the crawler to stop.

post.description: Sets the schedule state of the specified crawler to NOT_SCHEDULED, but does not stop the crawler if it is already running.

CrawlerName.description: Name of the crawler whose schedule state to set.

post.description: Stops a specified trigger.

Name.description: The name of the trigger that was stopped.
The name of the trigger to stop.

post.description: Adds tags to a resource. A tag is a label you can assign to an AWS resource. In AWS Glue, you can tag only certain resources. For information about what resources you can tag, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue.

ResourceArn.description: The ARN of the AWS Glue resource to which to add the tags. For more information about AWS Glue resource ARNs, see the AWS Glue ARN string pattern.

TagsToAdd.description: Tags to add to this resource.

post.description: Removes tags from a resource.

ResourceArn.description: The ARN of the resource from which to remove the tags.

TagsToRemove.description: Tags to remove from this resource.

post.description: Modifies an existing classifier (a GrokClassifier, XMLClassifier, or JsonClassifier, depending on which field is present).

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches, such as Twitter, JSON, Omniture logs, Amazon CloudWatch Logs, and so on.

CustomPatterns.description: Optional custom grok patterns used by this classifier.

GrokPattern.description: The grok pattern used by this classifier.

JsonPath.description: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. AWS Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

RowTag.description: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. Note that this cannot identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

post.description: Updates a connection definition in the Data Catalog.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connection resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

ConnectionInput.description: A ConnectionInput object that redefines the connection in question.

ConnectionProperties.description: These key-value pairs define parameters for the connection.

ConnectionType.description: The type of the connection. Currently, only JDBC is supported; SFTP is not supported.

MatchCriteria.description: A list of criteria that can be used in selecting this connection.

PhysicalConnectionRequirements.description: A map of physical connection requirements, such as virtual private cloud (VPC) and SecurityGroup, that are needed to successfully make this connection.

AvailabilityZone.description: The connection's Availability Zone. This field is redundant because the specified subnet implies the Availability Zone to be used. Currently the field must be populated, but it will be deprecated in the future.

SecurityGroupIdList.description: The security group ID list used by the connection.

SubnetId.description: The subnet ID used by the connection.

Name.description: The name of the connection definition to update.

post.description: Updates a crawler. If a crawler is running, you must stop it using StopCrawler before updating it.

Classifiers.description: A list of custom classifiers that the user has registered. By default, all built-in classifiers are included in a crawl, but these custom classifiers always override the default classifiers for a given classification.

Configuration.description: Crawler configuration information. This versioned JSON string allows users to specify aspects of a crawler's behavior. For more information, see Configuring a Crawler.

CrawlerSecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used by this Crawler.

DatabaseName.description: The AWS Glue database where results are stored, such as: arn:aws:daylight:us-east-1::database/sometable/*.

Description.description: A description of the new crawler.

Role.description: The IAM role (or ARN of an IAM role) used by the new crawler to access customer resources.

Schedule.description: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

SchemaChangePolicy.description: Policy for the crawler's update and deletion behavior.

DeleteBehavior.description: The deletion behavior when the crawler finds a deleted object.

UpdateBehavior.description: The update behavior when the crawler finds a changed schema.

TablePrefix.description: The table prefix used for catalog tables that are created.

Targets.description: A list of targets to crawl.

items.description: Specifies a DynamoDB table to crawl.

Path.description: The name of the DynamoDB table to crawl.

items.description: Specifies a JDBC data store to crawl.

ConnectionName.description: The name of the connection to use to connect to the JDBC target.

Exclusions.description: A list of glob patterns used to exclude from the crawl. For more information, see Catalog Tables with a Crawler.

Path.description: The path of the JDBC target.

items.description: Specifies a data store in Amazon S3.

Exclusions.description: A list of glob patterns used to exclude from the crawl. For more information, see Catalog Tables with a Crawler.

Path.description: The path to the Amazon S3 target.

post.description: Updates the schedule of a crawler using a cron expression.

CrawlerName.description: Name of the crawler whose schedule to update.

Schedule.description: The updated cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

post.description: Updates an existing database definition in a Data Catalog.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the metadata database resides. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseInput.description: A DatabaseInput object specifying the new definition of the metadata database in the catalog.

LocationUri.description: The location of the database (for example, an HDFS path).

Name.description: Name of the database. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

Parameters.description: Thes key-value pairs define parameters and properties of the database.

Name.description: The name of the database to update in the catalog. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase.

post.description: Updates a specified DevEndpoint.

AddArguments.description: The map of arguments to add the map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

AddPublicKeys.description: The list of public keys for the DevEndpoint to use.

CustomLibraries.description: Custom Python or Java libraries to be loaded in the DevEndpoint.

ExtraJarsS3Path.description:
Path to one or more Java Jars in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

Please note that only pure Java/Scala libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.description:
Path(s) to one or more Python libraries in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

Please note that only pure Python libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not yet supported.

DeleteArguments.description: The list of argument keys to be deleted from the map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

DeletePublicKeys.description: The list of public keys to be deleted from the DevEndpoint.

EndpointName.description: The name of the DevEndpoint to be updated.

PublicKey.description: The public key for the DevEndpoint to use.

UpdateEtlLibraries.description: True if the list of custom libraries to be loaded in the development endpoint needs to be updated, or False otherwise.

post.description: Updates an existing job definition.

JobName.description: Returns the name of the updated job definition.
Name of the job definition to update.

JobUpdate.description: Specifies the values with which to update the job definition.

AllocatedCapacity.description:
This field is deprecated. Use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) to allocate to this Job. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

Command.description: The JobCommand that executes this job (required).

Name.description: The name of the job command: this must be glueetl, for an Apache Spark ETL job, or pythonshell, for a Python shell job.

ScriptLocation.description: Specifies the S3 path to a script that executes a job (required).

Connections.description: The connections used for this job.
A list of connections used by the job.

DefaultArguments.description:
The default arguments for this job.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

Description.description: Description of the job being defined.

ExecutionProperty.description: An ExecutionProperty specifying the maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for this job.

MaxConcurrentRuns.description: The maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for the job. The default is 1. An error is returned when this threshold is reached. The maximum value you can specify is controlled by a service limit.

LogUri.description: This field is reserved for future use.

MaxCapacity.description:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

MaxRetries.description: The maximum number of times to retry this job if it fails.

NotificationProperty.description: Specifies configuration properties of a job notification.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

Role.description: The name or ARN of the IAM role associated with this job (required).

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job.

Timeout.description: The job timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

post.description: Updates a partition.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partition to be updated resides. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.description: The name of the catalog database in which the table in question resides.

PartitionInput.description: The new partition object to which to update the partition.

LastAccessTime.description: The last time at which the partition was accessed.

LastAnalyzedTime.description: The last time at which column statistics were computed for this partition.

Parameters.description: These key-value pairs define partition parameters.

StorageDescriptor.description: Provides information about the physical location where the partition is stored.

BucketColumns.description: A list of reducer grouping columns, clustering columns, and bucketing columns in the table.

Columns.description: A list of the Columns in the table.

items.description: A column in a Table.

Type.description: The datatype of data in the Column.

Compressed.description: True if the data in the table is compressed, or False if not.

InputFormat.description: The input format: SequenceFileInputFormat (binary), or TextInputFormat, or a custom format.

Location.description: The physical location of the table. By default this takes the form of the warehouse location, followed by the database location in the warehouse, followed by the table name.

NumberOfBuckets.description: Must be specified if the table contains any dimension columns.

OutputFormat.description: The output format: SequenceFileOutputFormat (binary), or IgnoreKeyTextOutputFormat, or a custom format.

Parameters.description: User-supplied properties in key-value form.
These key-value pairs define initialization parameters for the SerDe.

SerializationLibrary.description: Usually the class that implements the SerDe. An example is: org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.columnar.ColumnarSerDe.

SkewedInfo.description: Information about values that appear very frequently in a column (skewed values).

SkewedColumnNames.description: A list of names of columns that contain skewed values.

SkewedColumnValueLocationMaps.description: A mapping of skewed values to the columns that contain them.

SkewedColumnValues.description: A list of values that appear so frequently as to be considered skewed.

SortColumns.description: A list specifying the sort order of each bucket in the table.

items.description: Specifies the sort order of a sorted column.

SortOrder.description: Indicates that the column is sorted in ascending order (== 1), or in descending order (==0).

StoredAsSubDirectories.description: True if the table data is stored in subdirectories, or False if not.

Values.description: The values of the partition. Although this parameter is not required by the SDK, you must specify this parameter for a valid input.

PartitionValueList.description: A list of the values defining the partition.

TableName.description: The name of the table where the partition to be updated is located.

post.description: Updates a metadata table in the Data Catalog.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog where the table resides. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.description: The name of the catalog database in which the table resides. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

SkipArchive.description: By default, UpdateTable always creates an archived version of the table before updating it. If skipArchive is set to true, however, UpdateTable does not create the archived version.

TableInput.description: An updated TableInput object to define the metadata table in the catalog.

LastAccessTime.description: Last time the table was accessed.

LastAnalyzedTime.description: Last time column statistics were computed for this table.

Name.description: Name of the table. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

Parameters.description: These key-value pairs define properties associated with the table.

PartitionKeys.description:
A list of columns by which the table is partitioned. Only primitive types are supported as partition keys.

When creating a table used by Athena, and you do not specify any partitionKeys, you must at least set the value of partitionKeys to an empty list. For example:

"PartitionKeys": []

items.description: A column in a Table.

Type.description: The datatype of data in the Column.

StorageDescriptor.description: A storage descriptor containing information about the physical storage of this table.

BucketColumns.description: A list of reducer grouping columns, clustering columns, and bucketing columns in the table.

Columns.description: A list of the Columns in the table.

items.description: A column in a Table.

Type.description: The datatype of data in the Column.

Compressed.description: True if the data in the table is compressed, or False if not.

InputFormat.description: The input format: SequenceFileInputFormat (binary), or TextInputFormat, or a custom format.

Location.description: The physical location of the table. By default this takes the form of the warehouse location, followed by the database location in the warehouse, followed by the table name.

NumberOfBuckets.description: Must be specified if the table contains any dimension columns.

OutputFormat.description: The output format: SequenceFileOutputFormat (binary), or IgnoreKeyTextOutputFormat, or a custom format.

Parameters.description: User-supplied properties in key-value form.
These key-value pairs define initialization parameters for the SerDe.

SerializationLibrary.description: Usually the class that implements the SerDe. An example is: org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.columnar.ColumnarSerDe.

SkewedInfo.description: Information about values that appear very frequently in a column (skewed values).

SkewedColumnNames.description: A list of names of columns that contain skewed values.

SkewedColumnValueLocationMaps.description: A mapping of skewed values to the columns that contain them.

SkewedColumnValues.description: A list of values that appear so frequently as to be considered skewed.

SortColumns.description: A list specifying the sort order of each bucket in the table.

items.description: Specifies the sort order of a sorted column.

SortOrder.description: Indicates that the column is sorted in ascending order (== 1), or in descending order (==0).

StoredAsSubDirectories.description: True if the table data is stored in subdirectories, or False if not.

TableType.description: The type of this table (EXTERNAL_TABLE, VIRTUAL_VIEW, etc.).

ViewExpandedText.description: If the table is a view, the expanded text of the view; otherwise null.

ViewOriginalText.description: If the table is a view, the original text of the view; otherwise null.

Id.description: Reserved for future use.

Conditions.description: A list of the conditions that determine when the trigger will fire.

items.description: Defines a condition under which a trigger fires.

Type.description: The type of trigger that this is.

Name.description: The name of the trigger to update.

AvailabilityZone.description: The AWS availability zone where this DevEndpoint is located.

ExtraJarsS3Path.description:
Path to one or more Java Jars in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

Please note that only pure Java/Scala libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.description:
Path(s) to one or more Python libraries in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

Please note that only pure Python libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not yet supported.

FailureReason.description: The reason for a current failure in this DevEndpoint.

LastUpdateStatus.description: The status of the last update.

PrivateAddress.description: A private IP address to access the DevEndpoint within a VPC, if the DevEndpoint is created within one. The PrivateAddress field is present only when you create the DevEndpoint within your virtual private cloud (VPC).

PublicAddress.description: The public IP address used by this DevEndpoint. The PublicAddress field is present only when you create a non-VPC (virtual private cloud) DevEndpoint.

PublicKey.description: The public key to be used by this DevEndpoint for authentication. This attribute is provided for backward compatibility, as the recommended attribute to use is public keys.

PublicKeys.description:
A list of public keys to be used by the DevEndpoints for authentication. The use of this attribute is preferred over a single public key because the public keys allow you to have a different private key per client.

If you previously created an endpoint with a public key, you must remove that key to be able to set a list of public keys: call the UpdateDevEndpoint API with the public key content in the deletePublicKeys attribute, and the list of new keys in the addPublicKeys attribute.

This field is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) allocated to runs of this job. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

MaxCapacity.description:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

Classifier.description:
Classifiers are triggered during a crawl task. A classifier checks whether a given file is in a format it can handle, and if it is, the classifier creates a schema in the form of a StructType object that matches that data format.

You can use the standard classifiers that AWS Glue supplies, or you can write your own classifiers to best categorize your data sources and specify the appropriate schemas to use for them. A classifier can be a grok classifier, an XML classifier, or a JSON classifier, as specified in one of the fields in the Classifier object.

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches, such as Twitter, JSON, Omniture logs, and so on.

CreationTime.description: The time this classifier was registered.

CustomPatterns.description: Optional custom grok patterns defined by this classifier. For more information, see custom patterns in Writing Custom Classifers.

GrokPattern.description: The grok pattern applied to a data store by this classifier. For more information, see built-in patterns in Writing Custom Classifers.

LastUpdated.description: The time this classifier was last updated.

CreationTime.description: The time this classifier was registered.

JsonPath.description: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. AWS Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

LastUpdated.description: The time this classifier was last updated.

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

CreationTime.description: The time this classifier was registered.

LastUpdated.description: The time this classifier was last updated.

RowTag.description: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. Note that this cannot identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

Connection.description: Defines a connection to a data source.

ConnectionProperties.description:
These key-value pairs define parameters for the connection:

  • HOST - The host URI: either the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) or the IPv4 address of the database host.

  • PORT - The port number, between 1024 and 65535, of the port on which the database host is listening for database connections.

  • USER_NAME - The name under which to log in to the database. The value string for USER_NAME is "USERNAME".

  • PASSWORD - A password, if one is used, for the user name.

  • ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD - When you enable connection password protection by setting ConnectionPasswordEncryption in the Data Catalog encryption settings, this field stores the encrypted password.

  • JDBC_DRIVER_JAR_URI - The Amazon S3 path of the JAR file that contains the JDBC driver to use.

  • JDBC_DRIVER_CLASS_NAME - The class name of the JDBC driver to use.

  • JDBC_ENGINE - The name of the JDBC engine to use.

  • JDBC_ENGINE_VERSION - The version of the JDBC engine to use.

  • CONFIG_FILES - (Reserved for future use).

  • INSTANCE_ID - The instance ID to use.

  • JDBC_CONNECTION_URL - The URL for the JDBC connection.

  • JDBC_ENFORCE_SSL - A Boolean string (true, false) specifying whether Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) with hostname matching will be enforced for the JDBC connection on the client. The default is false.

ConnectionType.description: The type of the connection. Currently, only JDBC is supported; SFTP is not supported.

CreationTime.description: The time that this connection definition was created.

LastUpdatedBy.description: The user, group, or role that last updated this connection definition.

LastUpdatedTime.description: The last time that this connection definition was updated.

MatchCriteria.description: A list of criteria that can be used in selecting this connection.

Name.description: The name of the connection definition.

PhysicalConnectionRequirements.description: A map of physical connection requirements, such as virtual private cloud (VPC) and SecurityGroup, that are needed to make this connection successfully.

AvailabilityZone.description: The connection's Availability Zone. This field is redundant because the specified subnet implies the Availability Zone to be used. Currently the field must be populated, but it will be deprecated in the future.

SecurityGroupIdList.description: The security group ID list used by the connection.

SubnetId.description: The subnet ID used by the connection.

ConnectionPasswordEncryption.description:
The data structure used by the Data Catalog to encrypt the password as part of CreateConnection or UpdateConnection and store it in the ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD field in the connection properties. You can enable catalog encryption or only password encryption.

When a CreationConnection request arrives containing a password, the Data Catalog first encrypts the password using your AWS KMS key. It then encrypts the whole connection object again if catalog encryption is also enabled.

This encryption requires that you set AWS KMS key permissions to enable or restrict access on the password key according to your security requirements. For example, you might want only admin users to have decrypt permission on the password key.

AwsKmsKeyId.description:
An AWS KMS key that is used to encrypt the connection password.

If connection password protection is enabled, the caller of CreateConnection and UpdateConnection needs at least kms:Encrypt permission on the specified AWS KMS key, to encrypt passwords before storing them in the Data Catalog.

You can set the decrypt permission to enable or restrict access on the password key according to your security requirements.

ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted.description: When the ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted flag is set to "true", passwords remain encrypted in the responses of GetConnection and GetConnections. This encryption takes effect independently from catalog encryption.

Crawler.description: Specifies a crawler program that examines a data source and uses classifiers to try to determine its schema. If successful, the crawler records metadata concerning the data source in the AWS Glue Data Catalog.

Classifiers.description: A list of custom classifiers associated with the crawler.

Configuration.description: Crawler configuration information. This versioned JSON string allows users to specify aspects of a crawler's behavior. For more information, see Configuring a Crawler.

CrawlElapsedTime.description: If the crawler is running, contains the total time elapsed since the last crawl began.

CrawlerSecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used by this Crawler.

CreationTime.description: The time when the crawler was created.

DatabaseName.description: The database where metadata is written by this crawler.

LastCrawl.description: The status of the last crawl, and potentially error information if an error occurred.

ErrorMessage.description: If an error occurred, the error information about the last crawl.

LogGroup.description: The log group for the last crawl.

LogStream.description: The log stream for the last crawl.

MessagePrefix.description: The prefix for a message about this crawl.

StartTime.description: The time at which the crawl started.

LastUpdated.description: The time the crawler was last updated.

Schedule.description: For scheduled crawlers, the schedule when the crawler runs.

ScheduleExpression.description: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

State.description: The state of the schedule.

SchemaChangePolicy.description: Sets the behavior when the crawler finds a changed or deleted object.

DeleteBehavior.description: The deletion behavior when the crawler finds a deleted object.

UpdateBehavior.description: The update behavior when the crawler finds a changed schema.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.description:
Path(s) to one or more Python libraries in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

Please note that only pure Python libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not yet supported.

NumberOfNodes.description: The number of AWS Glue Data Processing Units (DPUs) to allocate to this DevEndpoint.

PublicKey.description: The public key to be used by this DevEndpoint for authentication. This attribute is provided for backward compatibility, as the recommended attribute to use is public keys.

PublicKeys.description:
A list of public keys to be used by the DevEndpoints for authentication. The use of this attribute is preferred over a single public key because the public keys allow you to have a different private key per client.

If you previously created an endpoint with a public key, you must remove that key to be able to set a list of public keys: call the UpdateDevEndpoint API with the public key content in the deletePublicKeys attribute, and the list of new keys in the addPublicKeys attribute.

CustomPatterns.description: Optional custom grok patterns used by this classifier.

AllocatedCapacity.description:
This parameter is deprecated. Use MaxCapacity instead.

The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) to allocate to this Job. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

This property is deprecated, use MaxCapacity instead.

Command.description: The JobCommand that executes this job.

Name.description: The name of the job command: this must be glueetl, for an Apache Spark ETL job, or pythonshell, for a Python shell job.

ScriptLocation.description: Specifies the S3 path to a script that executes a job (required).

Connections.description: The connections used for this job.
A list of connections used by the job.

DefaultArguments.description:
The default arguments for this job.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

Description.description: Description of the job being defined.

ExecutionProperty.description: An ExecutionProperty specifying the maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for this job.

MaxConcurrentRuns.description: The maximum number of concurrent runs allowed for the job. The default is 1. An error is returned when this threshold is reached. The maximum value you can specify is controlled by a service limit.

LogUri.description: This field is reserved for future use.

MaxCapacity.description:
The number of AWS Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the AWS Glue pricing page.

The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:

  • When you specify a python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.

  • When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

MaxRetries.description: The maximum number of times to retry this job if it fails.

Name.description: The name you assign to this job definition. It must be unique in your account.

NotificationProperty.description: Specifies configuration properties of a job notification.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

Role.description: The name or ARN of the IAM role associated with this job.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job.

Tags.description: The tags to use with this job. You may use tags to limit access to the job. For more information about tags in AWS Glue, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue in the developer guide.

Timeout.description: The job timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

Name.description: The unique name that was provided for this job definition.

LastAnalyzedTime.description: The last time at which column statistics were computed for this partition.

Columns.description: A list of the Columns in the table.

items.description: A column in a Table.

Compressed.description: True if the data in the table is compressed, or False if not.

InputFormat.description: The input format: SequenceFileInputFormat (binary), or TextInputFormat, or a custom format.

Location.description: The physical location of the table. By default this takes the form of the warehouse location, followed by the database location in the warehouse, followed by the table name.

NumberOfBuckets.description: Must be specified if the table contains any dimension columns.

OutputFormat.description: The output format: SequenceFileOutputFormat (binary), or IgnoreKeyTextOutputFormat, or a custom format.

Parameters.description: User-supplied properties in key-value form.
These key-value pairs define initialization parameters for the SerDe.

SerializationLibrary.description: Usually the class that implements the SerDe. An example is: org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.columnar.ColumnarSerDe.

SkewedInfo.description: Information about values that appear very frequently in a column (skewed values).

SkewedColumnNames.description: A list of names of columns that contain skewed values.

SkewedColumnValueLocationMaps.description: A mapping of skewed values to the columns that contain them.

SkewedColumnValues.description: A list of values that appear so frequently as to be considered skewed.

SortColumns.description: A list specifying the sort order of each bucket in the table.

items.description: Specifies the sort order of a sorted column.

SortOrder.description: Indicates that the column is sorted in ascending order (== 1), or in descending order (==0).

StoredAsSubDirectories.description: True if the table data is stored in subdirectories, or False if not.

Values.description: The values of the partition. Although this parameter is not required by the SDK, you must specify this parameter for a valid input.

TableName.description: The name of the metadata table in which the partition is to be created.

Name.description: The name for the new security configuration.

CreatedTimestamp.description: The time at which the new security configuration was created.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the Table. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.description: The catalog database in which to create the new table. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

TableInput.description: The TableInput object that defines the metadata table to create in the catalog.

LastAccessTime.description: Last time the table was accessed.

LastAnalyzedTime.description: Last time column statistics were computed for this table.

Name.description: Name of the table. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

Parameters.description: These key-value pairs define properties associated with the table.

PartitionKeys.description:
A list of columns by which the table is partitioned. Only primitive types are supported as partition keys.

When creating a table used by Athena, and you do not specify any partitionKeys, you must at least set the value of partitionKeys to an empty list. For example:

"PartitionKeys": []

items.description: A column in a Table.

Type.description: The datatype of data in the Column.

StorageDescriptor.description: A storage descriptor containing information about the physical storage of this table.

BucketColumns.description: A list of reducer grouping columns, clustering columns, and bucketing columns in the table.

Columns.description: A list of the Columns in the table.

items.description: A column in a Table.

Type.description: The datatype of data in the Column.

Compressed.description: True if the data in the table is compressed, or False if not.

InputFormat.description: The input format: SequenceFileInputFormat (binary), or TextInputFormat, or a custom format.

Location.description: The physical location of the table. By default this takes the form of the warehouse location, followed by the database location in the warehouse, followed by the table name.

NumberOfBuckets.description: Must be specified if the table contains any dimension columns.

OutputFormat.description: The output format: SequenceFileOutputFormat (binary), or IgnoreKeyTextOutputFormat, or a custom format.

Parameters.description: User-supplied properties in key-value form.
These key-value pairs define initialization parameters for the SerDe.

SerializationLibrary.description: Usually the class that implements the SerDe. An example is: org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.columnar.ColumnarSerDe.

SkewedInfo.description: Information about values that appear very frequently in a column (skewed values).

SkewedColumnNames.description: A list of names of columns that contain skewed values.

SkewedColumnValueLocationMaps.description: A mapping of skewed values to the columns that contain them.

SkewedColumnValues.description: A list of values that appear so frequently as to be considered skewed.

SortColumns.description: A list specifying the sort order of each bucket in the table.

items.description: Specifies the sort order of a sorted column.

SortOrder.description: Indicates that the column is sorted in ascending order (== 1), or in descending order (==0).

StoredAsSubDirectories.description: True if the table data is stored in subdirectories, or False if not.

TableType.description: The type of this table (EXTERNAL_TABLE, VIRTUAL_VIEW, etc.).

ViewExpandedText.description: If the table is a view, the expanded text of the view; otherwise null.

ViewOriginalText.description: If the table is a view, the original text of the view; otherwise null.

Actions.description: The actions initiated by this trigger when it fires.

items.description: Defines an action to be initiated by a trigger.

Arguments.description:
The job arguments used when this trigger fires. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that AWS Glue itself consumes.

For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling AWS Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.

For information about the key-value pairs that AWS Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by AWS Glue topic in the developer guide.

JobName.description: The name of a job to be executed.

NotificationProperty.description: Specifies configuration properties of a job run notification.

NotifyDelayAfter.description: After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this action.

Timeout.description: The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

Description.description: A description of the new trigger.

Predicate.description:
A predicate to specify when the new trigger should fire.

This field is required when the trigger type is CONDITIONAL.

Conditions.description: A list of the conditions that determine when the trigger will fire.

items.description: Defines a condition under which a trigger fires.

JobName.description: The name of the Job to whose JobRuns this condition applies and on which this trigger waits.

State.description: The condition state. Currently, the values supported are SUCCEEDED, STOPPED, TIMEOUT and FAILED.

Logical.description: Optional field if only one condition is listed. If multiple conditions are listed, then this field is required.

Schedule.description:
A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

This field is required when the trigger type is SCHEDULED.

StartOnCreation.description: Set to true to start SCHEDULED and CONDITIONAL triggers when created. True not supported for ON_DEMAND triggers.

Tags.description: The tags to use with this trigger. You may use tags to limit access to the trigger. For more information about tags in AWS Glue, see AWS Tags in AWS Glue in the developer guide.

Type.description: The type of the new trigger.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the function. If none is supplied, the AWS account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.description: The name of the catalog database in which to create the function.

FunctionInput.description: A FunctionInput object that defines the function to create in the Data Catalog.

ClassName.description: The Java class that contains the function code.

ResourceUris.description: The resource URIs for the function.

items.description: URIs for function resources.

Uri.description: The URI for accessing the resource.

CreateXMLClassifierRequest.description: Specifies an XML classifier for CreateClassifier to create.

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

RowTag.description: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. Note that this cannot identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

DataCatalogEncryptionSettings.description: Contains configuration information for maintaining Data Catalog security.

ConnectionPasswordEncryption.description: When connection password protection is enabled, the Data Catalog uses a customer-provided key to encrypt the password as part of CreateConnection or UpdateConnection and store it in the ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD field in the connection properties. You can enable catalog encryption or only password encryption.

AwsKmsKeyId.description:
An AWS KMS key that is used to encrypt the connection password.

If connection password protection is enabled, the caller of CreateConnection and UpdateConnection needs at least kms:Encrypt permission on the specified AWS KMS key, to encrypt passwords before storing them in the Data Catalog.

You can set the decrypt permission to enable or restrict access on the password key according to your security requirements.

ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted.description: When the ReturnConnectionPasswordEncrypted flag is set to "true", passwords remain encrypted in the responses of GetConnection and GetConnections. This encryption takes effect independently from catalog encryption.

EncryptionAtRest.description: Specifies the encryption-at-rest configuration for the Data Catalog.

CatalogEncryptionMode.description: The encryption-at-rest mode for encrypting Data Catalog data.

SseAwsKmsKeyId.description: The ID of the AWS KMS key to use for encryption at rest.

DevEndpoint.description: A development endpoint where a developer can remotely debug ETL scripts.

Arguments.description:
A map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

Note that currently, we only support "--enable-glue-datacatalog": "" as a valid argument.

AvailabilityZone.description: The AWS availability zone where this DevEndpoint is located.

CreatedTimestamp.description: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was created.

ExtraJarsS3Path.description:
Path to one or more Java Jars in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint.

Please note that only pure Java/Scala libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint.

ExtraPythonLibsS3Path.description:
Path(s) to one or more Python libraries in an S3 bucket that should be loaded in your DevEndpoint. Multiple values must be complete paths separated by a comma.

Please note that only pure Python libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint. Libraries that rely on C extensions, such as the pandas Python data analysis library, are not yet supported.

FailureReason.description: The reason for a current failure in this DevEndpoint.

LastModifiedTimestamp.description: The point in time at which this DevEndpoint was last modified.

LastUpdateStatus.description: The status of the last update.

NumberOfNodes.description: The number of AWS Glue Data Processing Units (DPUs) allocated to this DevEndpoint.

PrivateAddress.description: A private IP address to access the DevEndpoint within a VPC, if the DevEndpoint is created within one. The PrivateAddress field is present only when you create the DevEndpoint within your virtual private cloud (VPC).

PublicAddress.description: The public IP address used by this DevEndpoint. The PublicAddress field is present only when you create a non-VPC (virtual private cloud) DevEndpoint.

PublicKey.description: The public key to be used by this DevEndpoint for authentication. This attribute is provided for backward compatibility, as the recommended attribute to use is public keys.

PublicKeys.description:
A list of public keys to be used by the DevEndpoints for authentication. The use of this attribute is preferred over a single public key because the public keys allow you to have a different private key per client.

If you previously created an endpoint with a public key, you must remove that key to be able to set a list of public keys: call the UpdateDevEndpoint API with the public key content in the deletePublicKeys attribute, and the list of new keys in the addPublicKeys attribute.

RoleArn.description: The AWS ARN of the IAM role used in this DevEndpoint.

SecurityConfiguration.description: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this DevEndpoint.

SecurityGroupIds.description: A list of security group identifiers used in this DevEndpoint.

Status.description: The current status of this DevEndpoint.

SubnetId.description: The subnet ID for this DevEndpoint.

VpcId.description: The ID of the virtual private cloud (VPC) used by this DevEndpoint.

YarnEndpointAddress.description: The YARN endpoint address used by this DevEndpoint.

ZeppelinRemoteSparkInterpreterPort.description: The Apache Zeppelin port for the remote Apache Spark interpreter.

DevEndpointCustomLibraries.description: Custom libraries to be loaded into a DevEndpoint.

Please note that only pure Java/Scala libraries can currently be used on a DevEndpoint.

items.description:
Classifiers are triggered during a crawl task. A classifier checks whether a given file is in a format it can handle, and if it is, the classifier creates a schema in the form of a StructType object that matches that data format.

You can use the standard classifiers that AWS Glue supplies, or you can write your own classifiers to best categorize your data sources and specify the appropriate schemas to use for them. A classifier can be a grok classifier, an XML classifier, or a JSON classifier, as specified in one of the fields in the Classifier object.

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches, such as Twitter, JSON, Omniture logs, and so on.

CreationTime.description: The time this classifier was registered.

CustomPatterns.description: Optional custom grok patterns defined by this classifier. For more information, see custom patterns in Writing Custom Classifers.

GrokPattern.description: The grok pattern applied to a data store by this classifier. For more information, see built-in patterns in Writing Custom Classifers.

LastUpdated.description: The time this classifier was last updated.

CreationTime.description: The time this classifier was registered.

JsonPath.description: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. AWS Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

LastUpdated.description: The time this classifier was last updated.

Classification.description: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

LastUpdated.description: The time this classifier was last updated.

An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

NextToken.description: A continuation token.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connection resides. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

HidePassword.description: Allows you to retrieve the connection metadata without returning the password. For instance, the AWS Glue console uses this flag to retrieve the connection, and does not display the password. Set this parameter when the caller might not have permission to use the AWS KMS key to decrypt the password, but does have permission to access the rest of the connection properties.

Name.description: The name of the connection definition to retrieve.

ConnectionProperties.description:
These key-value pairs define parameters for the connection:

  • HOST - The host URI: either the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) or the IPv4 address of the database host.

  • PORT - The port number, between 1024 and 65535, of the port on which the database host is listening for database connections.

  • USER_NAME - The name under which to log in to the database. The value string for USER_NAME is "USERNAME".

  • PASSWORD - A password, if one is used, for the user name.

  • ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD - When you enable connection password protection by setting ConnectionPasswordEncryption in the Data Catalog encryption settings, this field stores the encrypted password.

  • JDBC_DRIVER_JAR_URI - The Amazon S3 path of the JAR file that contains the JDBC driver to use.

  • JDBC_DRIVER_CLASS_NAME - The class name of the JDBC driver to use.

  • JDBC_ENGINE - The name of the JDBC engine to use.

  • JDBC_ENGINE_VERSION - The version of the JDBC engine to use.

  • CONFIG_FILES - (Reserved for future use).

  • INSTANCE_ID - The instance ID to use.

  • JDBC_CONNECTION_URL - The URL for the JDBC connection.

  • JDBC_ENFORCE_SSL - A Boolean string (true, false) specifying whether Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) with hostname matching will be enforced for the JDBC connection on the client. The default is false.

ConnectionType.description: The type of the connection. Currently, only JDBC is supported; SFTP is not supported.

CreationTime.description: The time that this connection definition was created.

LastUpdatedBy.description: The user, group, or role that last updated this connection definition.

LastUpdatedTime.description: The last time that this connection definition was updated.

MatchCriteria.description: A list of criteria that can be used in selecting this connection.

Name.description: The name of the connection definition.

PhysicalConnectionRequirements.description: A map of physical connection requirements, such as virtual private cloud (VPC) and SecurityGroup, that are needed to make this connection successfully.

AvailabilityZone.description: The connection's Availability Zone. This field is redundant because the specified subnet implies the Availability Zone to be used. Currently the field must be populated, but it will be deprecated in the future.

SecurityGroupIdList.description: The security group ID list used by the connection.

SubnetId.description: The subnet ID used by the connection.

GetConnectionsFilter.description: Filters the connection definitions that are returned by the GetConnections API operation.

ConnectionType.description: The type of connections to return. Currently, only JDBC is supported; SFTP is not supported.

MatchCriteria.description: A criteria string that must match the criteria recorded in the connection definition for that connection definition to be returned.

CatalogId.description: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connections reside. If none is provided, the AWS account ID is used by default.

Filter.description: A filter that controls which connections will be returned.

ConnectionType.description: The type of connections to return. Currently, only JDBC is supported; SFTP is not supported.

MatchCriteria.description: A criteria string that must match the criteria recorded in the connection definition for that connection definition to be returned.

HidePassword.description: Allows you to retrieve the connection metadata without returning the password. For instance, the AWS Glue console uses this flag to retrieve the connection, and does not display the password. Set this parameter when the caller might not have permission to use the AWS KMS key to decrypt the password, but does have permission to access the rest of the connection properties.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of connections to return in one response.

NextToken.description: A continuation token, if this is a continuation call.

ConnectionList.description: A list of requested connection definitions.
